Nulls and Views 21 Schemas ‚Ä¢ Schemas provide the basic organization of the data ‚Ä¢ Views allow to tailor that logical organization to the needs of particular applications without changing the basic schema: ‚Ä¢ Orders in a given district ‚Ä¢ Orders in a period of time ‚Ä¢ Orders from a customer ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¶ 22 TPC-C schema Nulls and Views Analytics (TPC-H) ‚Ä¢ Databases for analytics often use a star schema: ‚Ä¢ Fact table (very big) with the central element of the schema ‚Ä¢ Dimension tables (typically smaller): with more data on the different attributes that are mentioned in the fact table ‚Ä¢ It helps separate the relevant operational data from information that might be needed but it is not central to processing, e.g., an order 23Nulls and Views Snowflake schema ‚Ä¢ In star schemas, the dimension tables and the fact table are not normalized ‚Ä¢ A snowflake schema is a star schema where the dimension tables are normalized (some or all of them). Normalization is applied to low cardinality attributes to remove redundancy 24Nulls and Views Modern analytics (TPC-DS): Snow-storm ‚Ä¢ Multiple snow-flake schemas linked to each other ‚Ä¢ TPC-DS ‚Ä¢ Large number of tables (26) ‚Ä¢ Large number of columns per table (38) ‚Ä¢ Multiple fact tables to enable joins between large tables (fact to fact joins) 25Nulls and Views View: Define a View ‚Ä¢ Then you can use <NAME_OF_VIEW> ‚Äújust like a table‚Äù. ‚Ä¢ There are fundamental differences, we will see later.
